Methyl radical (CH3•) is the critical precursor to generate C2 hydrocarbons in oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) reaction. It is crucial to explore how to efficiently generate CH3• and reveal the intrinsic principles behind it. In this study, we select MgO with a relatively simple structure as the research object, and probe the effects of the electronic state of active site on the CH3• generation by the density functional theory (DFT) calculation. The results show that the pure MgO with the different crystal surfaces as the benchmark models exhibit poor catalytic performance for CH3• generation; while Li doped MgO surface or subsurface that have the electron-deficient of active sites, exhibit excellent catalytic performance for it, which is attributed to that the electron-deficient of active sites are easier to receive electron of H and thereby promote the efficient generation of CH3•; pure MgO surface or subsurface with oxygen vacancy as well as Li doped MgO surface or subsurface with oxygen vacancy as the contrast models that have the electron-rich of active sites, exhibit poor catalytic performance. It can be obtained that the active site with electronic-deficient state is the key to the efficient generation of CH3•. The study can provide some guidance for designing high efficient OCM catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Oxidative coupling of methane Crystal surface Li dopant Oxygen vacancy Electronic state of active site Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Methane (CH4) is an important fossil energy, which widely exists in natural gas, coalbed gas, shale gas and other mineral resources [1,2]. Direct conversion of CH4 to high value-added chemicals is of great importance in the C1 catalytic conversion field [3,4]. Oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) to C2 hydrocarbons is a promising and economically valuable route to realize its high value conversion and utilization [5–7]. However, the OCM reaction path is very complex, which involves many steps, mainly including [8–10]: (1) methane dissociation to the adsorbed CH3 and H; (2) the adsorbed CH3 desorption into the gas phase to generate CH3•; (3) two CH3• coupling to generate the C2H6; (4) C2H6 dehydrogenation to generate the C2H4. Each of the above steps may bifurcate to proceed other elementary reactions, such as the CH bond excessive break and oxidation to COX [11,12]. Ishikawa et al. [13] have speculated that the elementary steps are up to hundreds in the OCM reaction, which makes it difficult to completely clarify its detailed reaction mechanism. Interestingly, Lunsford and his workers have detected the number of CH3• is directly related to the C2 hydrocarbons yield [14]. And, it is well known that CH3• coupling to generate the C2H6 is a spontaneous process with no energy barrier [15,16]. Therefore, the CH3• generation with high activity and selectivity can be used as the premise for judging the high efficient generation of C2 hydrocarbons. For the OCM reaction, the most commonly used catalyst is metal oxide catalyst, such as rare earth metal oxides (La2O3, CeO2) [17–19], transition metal oxides (Mn-Na2WO4/SiO2) [20–22], perovskite metal oxides (ABO3) [23–25] and alkali metal oxides (MgO, CaO) [26–28], where the rare earth metal oxides, transition metal oxides and perovskite metal oxides all possess complex crystal structures, which make them unsuitable to be used for investigating the OCM reaction mechanism. However, MgO as the typical alkaline earth metal oxide, possesses a relatively simple crystal structure, which is very suitable to be selected to investigate the OCM reaction mechanism and thereby can provide some theoretical insights for designing high-efficient OCM catalysts. As well known, MgO possesses different crystal surfaces in the OCM reaction. Aljama et al. [29] study methane dissociation on the MgO(111), MgO(110) and MgO(100) surfaces, and the results show that those surfaces exhibit different catalytic performance, which is due to the different coordination structures of lattice oxygen. Alkali metal Li is often used as second metal to modify the catalytic property of MgO in the OCM reaction [30–32]. Ito et al. [33,34] adopt electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) to investigate Li doped MgO catalytic the OCM reaction, and find that its catalytic activity is superior to that of pure MgO, which think that the increased performance is resulted from the electronic effect caused by Li doped, however, Qian et al. [35] think that it is resulted from the structure effect caused by Li doped. To sum up, we can know that Li doped MgO catalysts have been prepared and used for the OCM reaction in experiment, however it is not clear that the impact of Li dopant on the active sites of MgO catalyst and what are the intrinsic factors that affect the catalytic performance in Li doped MgO catalysts [35], which is necessary to explore and clarify it. Moreover, oxygen vacancy always exists on the catalyst surface in OCM reaction [36,37]. The effect of excess electrons caused by oxygen vacancy on La2O3 catalytic the OCM reaction has been investigated, and the results show that the excess electrons are gathered around the oxygen vacancy rather than localized in La atom to affect the catalytic performance [38]. Based on the above study, we find that there exists the following questions in the MgO catalyzing OCM reaction: (1) how to select representative elementary steps to clarify OCM reaction process; (2) what effects do the different crystal surfaces of MgO have on the OCM reaction? (3) what effects do alkali Li dopant and oxygen vacancy have on the electronic state of active site and catalytic performance, as well as what are the intrinsic factors that affect the catalytic performance? In order to solve the above questions, the reaction pathway of OCM reaction are firstly simplified, as shown in Scheme 1 , where the generation of CH3• with high activity and selectivity is approximately considered as the high efficient generation of C2 hydrocarbons. Once CH3 is captured by lattice oxygen or dehydrogenated, it would be oxidized to by-product COx [39–41]. Then, the models of the MgO(110), MgO(100) and MgO(310) surfaces are constructed and investigated to probe the effect of different MgO crystal surfaces on the generation of CH3• in OCM reaction, where the MgO(110) and MgO(100) surfaces are chosen because their surface energies are known to be very low and easily exposed to the outer surface of MgO catalysts [27]; the MgO(310) surface is chosen because it is the most representative stepped surface for the OCM reaction [13]. Therefore, the models of MgO(110), MgO(100) and MgO(310) surface, Li doped MgO surface or subsurface, pure MgO surface or subsurface with oxygen vacancy, as well as Li doped MgO surface or subsurface with oxygen vacancy are constructed and investigated, respectively, to probe the effects of the electronic state of active site on the generation of CH3• in OCM reaction. 2 Calculation details 2.1 Calculation methods In this work, all spin-polarized DFT calculations are performed by using the Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP) [42,43]. The projector augmented wave (PAW) potentials within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) and the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerh of (PBE) functional are applied to process the exchange-correlation potential [44–47]. The plane wave cutoff energy is set to be 400 eV. The convergence criterion of the force and energy on geometry optimization are 0.03 eV/Å and 1 × 10−5 eV, respectively. The climbing-image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) method is used to search the transition states (TSs) [48,49], and its force convergence criteria is less than 0.05 eV/Å [50], which is implied to find the saddle point between the known initial state and final state. In addition, the frequency analysis is performed on the structures of transition states, and when there exists only one imaginary frequency, the structure of the transition state is thought to be right. The adsorption free energy (G ads), activation free energy (G a) and reaction free energy (∆G) with the zero-point energy (ZPE) correction at the typical temperature condition (1023 K) [51] as well as the oxygen vacancy formation energy (E OV) are calculated, and the projected Crystal Orbital Hamilton Population (pCOHP) are analyzed. All details are presented in the Supplementary Materials. 2.2 Calculation models In the work, the lattice parameter of bulk MgO is firstly calculated, and its values is 4.199 Å, which is well consistent with the experimental values (4.217 Å) [52]. Then, to probe the effect of MgO different crystal surface on reaction, the models of MgO(110), MgO(100) and MgO(310) surfaces are constructed, respectively, where the MgO(110) surface contains the p(2 × 4) supercell size with six atom layers, the MgO(100) surface contains the p(3 × 3) supercell size with six atom layers, and the MgO(310) surface contains the p(2 × 2) supercell size with twelve atom layers. Based on the models of pure MgO surface, in order to probe the effect of Li doped surface on reaction, the models of Li doped MgO surface or subsurface is constructed by a Li atom substituting a Mg atom on pure MgO surface or subsurface, respectively. There exists six corresponding models, named as Lisur-MgO(110), Lisub-MgO(110), Lisur-MgO(100), Lisub-MgO(100), Lisur-MgO(310) and Lisub-MgO(310). Based on the study of pure MgO surface as well as Li doped MgO surface or subsurface, in order to probe the effect of oxygen vacancy on reaction, the models of pure MgO surface or subsurface with oxygen vacancy as well as Li doped MgO surface or subsurface with oxygen vacancy are constructed by removing one oxygen atom from the surface or subsurface, respectively. There exists eighteen corresponding models, named as MgO(110)-Ov(sur), MgO(110)-Ov(sub), Lisur-MgO(110)-Ov(sur), Lisur-MgO(110)-Ov(sub), Lisub-MgO(110)-Ov(sur), Lisub-MgO(110)-Ov(sub), MgO(100)-Ov(sur), MgO(100)-Ov(sub), Lisur-MgO(100)-Ov(sur), Lisur-MgO(100)-Ov(sub), Lisub-MgO(100)-Ov(sur), Lisub-MgO(100)-Ov(sub), MgO(310)-Ov(sur), MgO(310)-Ov(sub), Lisur-MgO(310)-Ov(sur), Lisur-MgO(310)-Ov(sub), Lisub-MgO(310)-Ov(sur), and Lisub-MgO(310)-Ov(sub). For the models of MgO(110) and MgO(100) as well as corresponding Li doped and oxygen vacancy models, the top four layers together with the adsorbates are allowed to relax, whereas the bottom two layers are fixed. For the models of MgO(310) as well as corresponding Li doped and oxygen vacancy models, the top eight layers together with the adsorbates are allowed to relax, whereas the bottom four layers are fixed. The (3 × 2 × 1), (3 × 3 × 1) and (3 × 2 × 1) K-point mesh are used for MgO(110), MgO(100) and MgO(310) surface as well as their corresponding Li doped and oxygen vacancy models, respectively. The vacuum height of 20 Å is set for all models to clean up the effects of interaction between adjacent slabs. And the top and side views of the optimized structure of all models are shown in Fig. 1 . The rationality of the selected models is also analyzed in detail, as presented in the supplementary materials. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The effects of different crystal surface of MgO on the CH3• generation 3.1.1 The band gap of different crystal surface of MgO The dissociation of methane to CH3• and H on catalyst depends on the ability of the catalyst receiving electrons to some extent [29]. The band gap of catalyst can reflect its ability to receive electrons. The larger band gap, the weaker the ability to receive electrons. Here, we calculate the density of states (DOSs) of the MgO(110), MgO(100) and MgO(310) surfaces and obtain their band gap values, which is 1.65 eV for the MgO(110) surface, 3.40 eV for the MgO(100) surface and 2.65 eV for the MgO(310) surface, as illustrated in Fig. 2 . We can know that the MgO(110) surface has the strongest ability to receive electrons, followed by the MgO(310) and MgO(100) surfaces. 3.1.2 The H adsorption free energy and oxygen vacancy formation energy on different crystal surface of MgO In addition to band gap, the H adsorption free energy and oxygen vacancy formation energy also can be considered as the important indicators to measure the ability of catalyst receiving electrons [38,53]. The stronger the H adsorption free energy or the weaker the oxygen vacancy formation energy, the stronger the ability to receive electrons. The H adsorption free energy and oxygen vacancy formation energy have been calculated on different crystal surface of MgO, as illustrated in Fig. 3 , indicating that the H adsorption free energies, G ads(H), are -1.00, 0.57 and -0.44 eV on the MgO(110), MgO(100) and MgO(310) surfaces, respectively; the oxygen vacancy formation energies, E OV(sur) and E OV(sub), are 5.19 and 6.43 eV, 6.32 and 6.87 eV, 5.60 and 6.52 eV on the MgO(110), MgO(100) and MgO(310) surfaces, respectively. These features all indicate that the MgO(110) surface has better ability of receiving electrons than MgO(310) and MgO(100) surface, which is consistent with the band gap analysis results. 3.1.3 CH3• generation on the pure MgO(110), MgO(100) and MgO(310) surfaces Based on the proposed reaction pathway (Scheme 1), we study the possible element reactions on the pure MgO surfaces at 1023 K, including the methane dissociation to form adsorbed CH3, adsorbed CH3 desorption into gas to generate CH3• or diffusion to nearby O site or further dehydrogenation. The corresponding potential energy diagrams and reaction structures are shown in the Fig. 4 . For the MgO(110) surface, methane is firstly dissociated into coadsorbed H and CH3, where H is adsorbed at O site and CH3 is adsorbed at Mg site, - the energy barrier and reaction heat are 0.73 and 0.17 eV, respectively, and the CH distance in methane changes from 1.103 to 2.200 Å in the final state. Subsequently, the adsorbed CH3 can react along three pathways: (1) the adsorbed CH3 desorbs into gas to generate the target product (CH3•), where the process needs to adsorb heat of 3.67 eV and the C-Mg distance increases to 9.925 Å in the final state from 2.217 Å; (2) the adsorbed CH3 diffuses to the nearby O site to be converted to a methoxy species (CH3O), where the process needs to adsorb heat of 2.50 eV and the CO distance is 1.440 Å; (3) the adsorbed CH3 undergoes dehydrogenation to generate methylene group (CH2), where the process needs to adsorb heat of 1.90 eV and the distance between the H and CH2 is 2.224 Å. For the MgO(100) surface, we find that when the coadsorbtion structure of H and CH3 are optimized, the H and CH3 would automatically generate methane, which suggests that dissociation of methane hardly occur. The result is consistent with the study by Ishikawa et al. [54], where the dissociation of methane cannot happen on the MgO(100) surface. For the MgO(310) surface, methane is firstly dissociated into coadsorbed H and CH3, where H is adsorbed at O site and CH3 is adsorbed at Mg site, and the energy barrier which it needs to overcome is 0.87 eV, meanwhile it adsorb heat of 0.67 eV. Additionally, the CH distance is grown to 1.957 Å in the final state from 1.107 Å. Subsequently, the adsorbed CH3 can react along two pathways: (1) the adsorbed CH3 desorbs into gas to produce the CH3•, which needs to adsorb heat of 3.63 eV, and the C-Mg distance increases to 9.915 from 2.201 Å; (2) the adsorbed CH3 diffusing to the nearby O site needs to adsorb heat of 3.41 eV, where the distance of CO in CH3O is 1.463 Å. However, the adsorbed CH3 cannot undergo dehydrogenation reaction, which is because the H and CH2 would automatically generate CH3 when the coadsorbtion structure of H and CH2 are optimized, so CH2 cannot be produced, which is different from the case on the MgO(110) surface. From the above research, we can know that the MgO(110) and MgO(310) surface show lower catalytic activity for the CH3• generation due to the high desorption energy of CH3 from the surface, where the MgO(110) surface is slightly superior to the MgO(310) surface, while the MgO(100) surface exhibits no catalytic activity. The result is consistent with the above calculated band gap values, G ads(H) and E OV values. 3.1.4 ELF and pCOHP analysis of CH3-Mg interaction on the pure MgO(110) and MgO(310) surfaces Based on the above study about the pure MgO surfaces, we can obtain that the MgO(110) and MgO(310) surfaces also show lower selectivity for the CH3• generation, which is because that the desorption energy of CH3 is higher than the energies of its migration and dissociation. The electron localization function (ELF) and projected Crystal Orbital Hamilton Population (pCOHP) can be used to microcosmically analysis the selectivity of CH3• by measuring the C-Mg bond strength [55]. The IpCOHP values are obtained by the integral of the x>0 under the Fermi level (black horizontal lines of Fig. 5 ). When IpCOHP value is negative, it means that the interaction is very strong [56]. It can be seen through Fig. 5 that ELF shows that the electron density is highly localized around the C atom, indicating that there exists a strong interaction between the C and Mg atoms, which is further validated by the pCOHP analysis, where the IpCOHP values are -0.36 and -0.39 eV on MgO(110) and MgO(310) surfaces, respectively. The strong interaction between the CH3 and the surface Mg site results in the high desorption energy of the CH3. 3.2 The effects of Li doped MgO surface or subsurface on the CH3• generation 3.2.1 The bader charge analysis of Li doped MgO surface or subsurface In order to modulate the catalytic performance of MgO, the models of Li doped MgO(110), MgO(100) and MgO(310) surface or subsurface are designed. We firstly calculate the bader charge of surface O atom that is nearby the Li atom on Li doped MgO surface or subsurface. The results show that the bader charge of surface O atom are -1.52, -1.52 and -1.41 |e| on Li doped MgO(110), MgO(100) and MgO(310) surface, -1.39, -1.57 and -1.34 |e| on Li doped MgO(110), MgO(100) and MgO(310) subsurface, which is higher than -1.59 |e| on pure MgO(110) surface, -1.63 |e| on pure MgO(100) surface, -1.62 |e| on pure MgO(310) surface, respectively, as illustrated in Fig. 6 , indicating that Li-O pair possesses electron-deficient state compared with the Mg-O pair. We can infer that Li-O pair has the stronger ability to receive electrons in the reaction. 3.2.2 The H adsorption free energy and oxygen vacancy formation energy on Li doped MgO surface or subsurface We further compare the H adsorption free energy and oxygen vacancy formation energy on the Li doped MgO surface or subsurface with those on pure MgO surface. As illustrated in Fig. 7 and Table S2, G ads(H) are -3.62, -3.26 and -3.93 eV on the Li doped MgO(110), MgO(100) and MgO(310) surface, -3.30, -3.42 and -3.78 eV on the Li doped MgO(110), MgO(100) and MgO(310) subsurface, respectively, which is higher than the G ads(H) of -1.00, 0.57 and -0.44 eV on the MgO(110), MgO(100) and MgO(310) surface, respectively; E OV(sur) and E OV(sub) are 2.78 and 4.90 eV, 3.38 and 4.01 eV, 2.69 and 4.15 eV on the Li doped MgO(110), MgO(100) and MgO(310) surface, 2.99 and 4.80 eV, 3.34 and 3.81 eV, 2.78 and 3.93 eV on the Li doped MgO(110), MgO(100) and MgO(310) subsurface, respectively, which is lower than the E OV(sur) and E OV(sub) of 5.19 and 6.43 eV, 6.32 and 6.87 eV, 5.60 and 6.52 eV on the MgO(110), MgO(100) and MgO(310) surface, respectively. The results show that Li doped all increase the H adsorption free energy and reduce the oxygen vacancy formation energy compared with the pure surfaces, indicating that Li doped MgO surface or subsurface have stronger ability to receive electrons, which is consistent with the bader charge analysis results. 3.2.3 CH3• generation on the Li doped MgO surface or subsurface Based on the reaction pathway as shown in Scheme 1, similarly, we study the element reactions on the Li doped MgO surface or subsurface at 1023 K. And the corresponding potential energy diagram and structures are shown in the Figs. 8-10 . For the Li doped MgO(110) surface, the methane is directly dissociated to H and CH3•, where the energy barrier and reaction heat are 0.71 and -0.02 eV, respectively, and the CH distance in methane varies from 1.107 to 2.909 Å in the final state. Then, the CH3• can be easily captured by nearby O site and converted into CH3O with the CO distance being 1.419 Å, which needs to release heat of 0.21 eV. For the Li doped MgO(110) subsurface, methane is firstly dissociated into coadsorbed H and CH3, and the reaction energy barrier to be overcome is 0.78 eV, and the exothermic heat is 0.05 eV. The distance of CH is enlarged from 1.109 to 2.712 Å in the final state. Subsequently, the adsorbed CH3 can react along three pathways, which is similar to the case on the pure MgO(110) surface: (1) the adsorbed CH3 desorbing into gas needs to adsorb heat of 0.80 eV and the C-Mg distance increases to 7.890 from 2.308 Å in the initial state; (2) the adsorbed CH3 diffusing to the nearby O site needs to release heat of 0.04 eV and the CO distance is 1.429 Å; (3) the adsorbed CH3 undergoing dehydrogenation needs to release heat of 0.42 eV and the CH distance is 3.465 Å. For the Li doped MgO(100) surface, firstly, the methane dissociation requires overcoming an energy barrier of 0.56 eV to generate adsorbed H and CH3•, and the reaction is exothermic with an energy of 0.11 eV. The CH distance changes from 1.100 to 2.213 Å in the final state, and the distance of the C-Mg is 2.788 Å. Then, the CH3 is captured by nearby O site, which needs to adsorb heat of 1.34 eV and the distance of CO is 1.450 Å. For the Li doped MgO(100) subsurface, the methane is firstly dissociated to H and CH3•, where the energy barrier and reaction heat are 0.61 and -0.13 eV, respectively. The CH distance changes from 1.101 to 2.607 Å in the final state. Additionally, the nearby O site capturing the CH3• needs to adsorb heat of 1.54 eV with the CO distance being 1.460 Å. For the Li doped MgO(310) surface, the first step is methane dissociation to H and CH3•. The process has a relatively small barrier of 0.34 eV and an exothermic reaction energy of 0.57 eV. And the CH distance varies from 1.105 to 2.483 Å in the final state. Subsequently, the CH3• is captured by the nearby O site and the process needs to adsorb heat of 0.38 eV with the CO distance being 1.428 Å. For the Li doped MgO(310) subsurface, the methane dissociation requires overcoming an energy barrier of 0.58 eV to generate adsorbed H and CH3•, and the reaction is exothermic with an energy of 0.40 eV. The CH distance changes from 1.106 to 2.927 Å in the final state. Then, the CH3• is captured by nearby O site, where the process needs to adsorb heat of 0.85 eV and the distance of CO is 1.446 Å. From the above research, we can obtain that for the pure MgO surfaces, the mode of methane dissociation to form CH3• is heterolytic cleavage reaction, and the energy barrier is 4.55 eV for the MgO(110) surface, 5.04 eV for the MgO(310) surface, and the methane cannot dissociation on the MgO(100) surface; however, for the Li doped MgO surface or subsurface except Lisub-MgO (110), the mode of methane dissociation to form CH3• is homolytic cleavage reaction, and the energy barrier are 1.42, 1.65 and 1.14 eV for the Li doped MgO(110), MgO(100) and MgO(310) surface, 1.48, 1.61 and 1.33 eV for the Li doped MgO(110), MgO(100) and MgO(310) subsurface. It can be seen that the mode of methane dissociation is changed from heterolytic cleavage to homolytic cleavage for the Li doped MgO surface or subsurface, thereby reducing the energy barrier of CH3• formation. The unique electron-deficient of active site is the key to change the mode of methane dissociation and reduce the energy barrier of CH3• formation. 3.2.4 Analysis of the relationship between C-H activation and H adsorption free energy on the Li doped MgO surface or subsurface As well known, the H adsorption free energy can be considered as the important indicator to measure the ability of catalyst receiving electrons. In this section, we analyze the relationship between the CH activation energy and the H adsorption free energy. The result show that there exists a volcano relationship, as shown in Fig. 11 . Noteworthy, Lisub-MgO (110) is a special point, not on the volcanic curve. It may be because that methane dissociation is the heterolytic cleavage reaction (generating co-adsorption of CH3 and H) on the Lisub-MgO(110), which is different from that methane dissociation is the homolytic cleavage reaction (generating CH3• and the adsorbed H) on the Lisur-MgO(110), Lisur-MgO(100), Lisub-MgO(100), Lisur-MgO(310) and Lisub-MgO(310). 3.2.5 Spin-polarized charge density analysis of methyl radical generation Spin-polarized charge densities is often used to microscopically analyze the electronic configurations of the homolytic cleavage and heterolytic cleavage reaction. Here, we calculate the spin-polarized charge densities of CH3 and H on the Li doped MgO surface or subsurface, as shown in the Fig. 12 . The results show that on the Lisur-MgO(110), Lisur-MgO(100), Lisub-MgO(100), Lisur-MgO(310) and Lisub-MgO(310), the electrons are localized to CH3•, indicating that there exists no interaction between the CH3• and the surface, which belongs to the feature of the homolytic cleavage reaction; however, on the Lisub-MgO(110) surface, the electrons are localized around the area of CH3 and surface, indicating that there exists interaction between CH3 and the surface, which belongs to the feature of the heterolytic cleavage reaction. 3.3 The effects of oxygen vacancy on the CH3• generation over the pure and Li doped MgO surface or subsurface 3.3.1 The bader charge analysis of pure MgO surface or subsurface with oxygen vacancy as well as Li doped MgO surface or subsurface with oxygen vacancy As the contrast, the pure MgO surface or subsurface with oxygen vacancy as well as Li doped MgO surface or subsurface with oxygen vacancy are designed to further investigate the effects of oxygen vacancy on catalytic performance. Here, we firstly investigate the bader charge change of O atom near the oxygen vacancy. The result show that the bader charge of surface O atom are -1.61, -1.68 and -1.62 |e| on the MgO(110), MgO(100) and MgO(310) surface with oxygen vacancy, -1.60, -1.64 and -1.64 |e| on the MgO(110), MgO(100) and MgO(310) subsurface with oxygen vacancy, respectively, as illustrated in Fig. 13 (a), which is lower than -1.59, -1.63 and -1.62 |e| on the pure MgO(110), MgO(100) and MgO(310) surface, respectively. When oxygen vacancy is present on surface of the Li doped MgO surface, the corresponding bader charge of surface O atom are -1.58, -1.64 and -1.60 |e| on the Li doped MgO(110), MgO(100) and MgO(310) surface; when oxygen vacancy is present on subsurface of the Li doped MgO surface, the corresponding bader charge of surface O atom are -1.59, -1.63 and -1.62 |e| on the Li doped MgO(110), MgO(100) and MgO(310) surface; when oxygen vacancy is present on surface of the Li doped MgO subsurface, the corresponding bader charge of surface O atom are -1.60, -1.69 and -1.61 |e| on the Li doped MgO(110), MgO(100) and MgO(310) subsurface; when oxygen vacancy is present on subsurface of the Li doped MgO subsurface, the corresponding bader charge of surface O atom are -1.57, -1.64 and -1.62 |e| on the Li doped MgO(110), MgO(100) and MgO(310) subsurface, respectively, as illustrated in Fig. 13(b), which is also lower than -1.52, -1.52 and -1.41 |e| on the Li doped MgO(110), MgO(100) and MgO(310) surface, -1.39, -1.57 and -1.34 |e| on the Li doped MgO(110), MgO(100) and MgO(310) subsurface. We can conclude that the electronic-deficient state is broken while electrons-rich state is formed on Li doped MgO surface or subsurface with oxygen vacancy. 3.3.2 The H adsorption free energy on pure MgO surface or subsurface with oxygen vacancy as well as Li doped MgO surface or subsurface with oxygen vacancy We study the H adsorption free energy on pure MgO surface or subsurface with oxygen vacancy as well as Li doped MgO surface or subsurface with oxygen vacancy. As illustrated in Fig. 14 and Table S3, G ads(H) are -0.86, 0.68 and -0.29 eV on the MgO(110), MgO(100) and MgO(310) surface with oxygen vacancy, -0.93, 0.57 and -0.40 eV on the MgO(110), MgO(100) and MgO(310) subsurface with oxygen vacancy, respectively. When oxygen vacancy is present on surface of the Li doped MgO surface, the G ads(H) are -1.24, -0.56 and -1.03 eV on the Li doped MgO(110), MgO(100) and MgO(310) surfaces; when oxygen vacancy is present on subsurface of the Li doped MgO surface, the G ads(H) are -1.94, -0.44 and -1.50 eV on the Li doped MgO(110), MgO(100) and MgO(310) surface; when oxygen vacancy is present on surface of the Li doped MgO subsurface, the G ads(H) are -1.66, -0.32 and -0.89 eV on the Li doped MgO(110), MgO(100) and MgO(310) subsurface; when oxygen vacancy is present on subsurface of the Li doped MgO subsurface, the G ads(H) are -2.08, -0.51 and -1.49 eV on the Li doped MgO(110), MgO(100) and MgO(310) subsurface, respectively. It can be obtained that the H adsorption free energy is weakened on Li doped MgO surface or subsurface with oxygen vacancy, indicating that they have the weaker ability to receive electrons compared to Li doped MgO surfaces or subsurface. 3.3.3 CH3• generation on pure MgO surface or subsurface with oxygen vacancy as well as Li doped MgO surface or subsurface with oxygen vacancy Similarly, we study the possible element reactions on pure MgO surface or subsurface with oxygen vacancy as well as Li doped MgO surface or subsurface with oxygen vacancy at 1023 K. The detailed description of the results are presented in the Supplementary Materials. We can obviously obtain that methane dissociation is the heterolytic cleavage reaction (generating co-adsorption of CH3 and H), which is similar to the case on the pure MgO surface, and pure MgO surface or subsurface with oxygen vacancy as well as Li doped MgO surface or subsurface with oxygen vacancy exhibit lower catalytic performance for CH3• generation than the Li doped MgO surface or subsurface. The result is consistent with the above mentioned their weaker ability to receive electrons compared with the Li doped MgO surface or subsurface. As illustrated in Fig. 15 , we can obtain that compared to pure MgO surfaces, the energy barriers of CH3• formation on Li doped MgO surface or subsurface are reduced by a wide margin. The primary reason is that the mode of methane dissociation is changed from heterolytic cleavage to homolytic cleavage for the Li doped MgO surface or subsurface. The unique electron-deficient of active site of the Li doped MgO surface or subsurface is the key to change the mode of methane dissociation and reduce the energy barrier of CH3• formation. However, on pure MgO surface or subsurface with oxygen vacancy as well as Li doped MgO surface or subsurface with oxygen vacancy, the presence of the oxygen vacancy results in that the electronic-deficient state of Li-O pair is broken while electrons-rich state is built, resulting in that they exhibit poor catalytic performance for CH3• generation. 3.3.4 ELF and pCOHP analysis of CH3-Mg interaction on pure MgO surface or subsurface with oxygen vacancy as well as Li doped MgO surface or subsurface The pure MgO surface or subsurface with oxygen vacancy as well as Li doped MgO surface or subsurface with oxygen vacancy also show lower selectivity for the CH3• generation, as shown in the Supplementary Materials. Similarly, the ELF and pCOHP are calculated to measure the C-Mg bond strength of the adsorbed CH3. As shown in the Fig. S4, ELF show that the electron density is highly localized around the C atom, and the IpCOHP values are -0.25 and -0.36 eV on the pure MgO(110) and MgO(310) surface with oxygen vacancy, -0.34 and -0.38 eV on the pure MgO(110) and MgO(310) subsurface with oxygen vacancy, respectively, indicating that the interaction exist between the C and Mg atom, which are similar to the pure MgO(110) and MgO(310) surface. As shown in the Figure S5 and Figure S6, the interaction also exists between the C and Mg atom on the Li doped MgO surface or subsurface with oxygen vacancy, which are verified by the ELF and pCOHP. When oxygen vacancy is present on surface of the Li doped MgO surface, the IpCOHP values are -0.19 and -0.19 eV on the Li doped MgO(110) and MgO(310) surface; when oxygen vacancy is present on subsurface of the Li doped MgO surface, the IpCOHP values are -0.17 and -0.18 eV on the Li doped MgO(110) and MgO(310) surface; when oxygen vacancy is present on surface of the Li doped MgO subsurface, the IpCOHP values are -0.31 and -0.48 eV on the Li doped MgO(110) and MgO(310) subsurface; when oxygen vacancy is present on subsurface of the Li doped MgO subsurface, the IpCOHP values are -0.49 and -0.36 eV on the Li doped MgO(110) and MgO(310) subsurface, respectively. These features all indicate that the CH3 are strongly adsorbed on these surfaces, resulting in that the adsorbed CH3 desorbing into gas state is difficult to happen. 4 Conclusion In this paper, the MgO catalyst with different crystal surfaces, Li doped and oxygen vacancy are systematically studied by DFT calculation to probe the effects of the electronic state of active site on the CH3• generation. The main conclusions are as follows: (1) For the pure MgO surfaces, MgO(110) and MgO(310) surface show lower catalytic activity and selectivity for the CH3• generation, while the MgO(100) surface exhibits no catalytic activity. For Li doped MgO surface or subsurface, Li doped MgO(110) surface or subsurface both can improve the catalytic activity, but not improve the selectivity for CH3• generation; Li doped MgO(100) and MgO(310) surface or subsurface not only can improve the catalytic activity, but also improve the selectivity. For the pure MgO surface or subsurface with oxygen vacancy as well as Li doped MgO surface or subsurface with oxygen vacancy, they all show lower activity and selectivity for the CH3• generation, which is similar to the case on the pure MgO surfaces. (2) For the Li doped MgO surface or subsurface, there exists a volcano relationship between the CH activation energy and the H adsorption free energy, where Lisub-MgO(110) is a special point, not on the volcanic curve. It may be because that methane dissociation is the heterolytic cleavage reaction on Lisub-MgO(110), which is different from the case (homolytic cleavage reaction) on the other Li doped MgO surface or subsurface. (3) Electronically, the Li doped MgO surface or subsurface possess the Li-O pair that is electron-deficient state comparing to the Mg-O pair, which is easier to receive electron of H and thereby generate CH3• with high catalytic performance in the OCM reaction. When the oxygen vacancy appear on the surface or subsurface, electronic-deficient state of Li-O pair will be broken while electrons-rich state will be formed, resulting in the decreased catalytic performance for CH3• generation. coredata.dc:description: Methyl radical (CH3•) is the critical precursor to generate C2 hydrocarbons in oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) reaction. It is crucial to explore how to efficiently generate CH3• and reveal the intrinsic principles behind it. In this study, we select MgO with a relatively simple structure as the research object, and probe the effects of the electronic state of active site on the CH3• generation by the density functional theory (DFT) calculation. The results show that the pure MgO with the different crystal surfaces as the benchmark models exhibit poor catalytic performance for CH3• generation; while Li doped MgO surface or subsurface that have the electron-deficient of active sites, exhibit excellent catalytic performance for it, which is attributed to that the electron-deficient of active sites are easier to receive electron of H and thereby promote the efficient generation of CH3•; pure MgO surface or subsurface with oxygen vacancy as well as Li doped MgO surface or subsurface with oxygen vacancy as the contrast models that have the electron-rich of active sites, exhibit poor catalytic performance. It can be obtained that the active site with electronic-deficient state is the key to the efficient generation of CH3•. The study can provide some guidance for designing high efficient OCM catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Boosting the generation of key intermediate methyl radical (CH3•) in OCM reaction on magnesium oxide catalysts by regulating the electronic state of the active site
